results.title: Michael Schultz Broke the Mold for Black Directors. He’s Not Done Yet.
results.abstract: At 83, the filmmaker behind “Cooley High” and “Car Wash” may be the longest-working Black director in history. His own story is a Hollywood epic.
des_facet: Sgt Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band (Movie)

multimedia.caption: Among other career milestones, Michael Schultz was responsible for the film debuts of Denzel Washington, Samuel L. Jackson and Blair Underwood.
multimedia.copyright: Nathan Bajar for The New York Times

results.title: With ‘Tár,’ Todd Field Returns to Directing. Where Has He Been?
results.abstract: Sixteen years after “In the Bedroom” and “Little Children” made waves, he’s nervous about stepping back into the limelight with a hot-button story.

multimedia.caption: Field said he got so used to working on unfilmed projects that “the idea that I was going to have to go away from home for over a year and actually make a film just seemed so absurd to me.”
multimedia.copyright: Tim Barber for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Field said he got so used to working on unfilmed projects that “the idea that I was going to have to go away from home for over a year and actually make a film just seemed so absurd to me.”

results.title: Jordan Peele Says There May Be More ‘Nope’ Stories to Come
results.abstract: We asked the writer-director about that standing shoe, a character called Nobody and fan theories about his flying-saucer movie. This is what he told us.

multimedia.caption: “I’m glad people are paying attention,” Jordan Peele said. “I do think they will get more answers on some of these things in the future.”
“I’m glad people are paying attention,” Jordan Peele said. “I do think they will get more answers on some of these things in the future.”

results.title: Where Did Those Hot Dog Fingers Come From? Daniels Explain
results.abstract: The directors of “Everything Everywhere All at Once” have found the reaction to their film “humbling and inspiring and confusing.”

multimedia.caption: Daniel Kwan, left, and Daniel Scheinert, the filmmakers behind “Everything Everywhere All at Once,” which has become A24’s highest-grossing release.

results.title: How Did ‘Top Gun: Maverick’ Get Those Dogfight Scenes? Joseph Kosinski Explains.
results.abstract: The director behind the biggest movie of 2022 so far discusses trying to make a movie that can’t be traced to any particular year and the meaning of Dad Cinema.

multimedia.caption: Joseph Kosinski was behind both “Top Gun: Maverick” and “Spiderhead,” released within a few weeks of each other. “It was a wonderful experience to be able to make both of those movies,” he said, but “from a releasing point of view, it was a lot.”

Joseph Kosinski was behind both “Top Gun: Maverick” and “Spiderhead,” released within a few weeks of each other. “It was a wonderful experience to be able to make both of those movies,” he said, but “from a releasing point of view, it was a lot.”

results.title: Venice: Noah Baumbach Finds the Music in ‘White Noise’
results.abstract: An end-credits dance scene, set to a new LCD Soundsystem song, is the talk of the fest. The director explains how it came together and what it means for “Barbie.”

results.title: Paul W.S. Anderson and Milla Jovovich: A Marriage Built on Monsters
results.abstract: In 20 years and several “Resident Evil” films, the couple has found their love language in action — and a lot of blood and dust.

multimedia.caption: The couple working on “Resident Evil: Afterlife.” She said, “Paul is the writer, I just ask questions.” He added, “But that’s a hugely important part of the process, and Milla’s really good on script.”

The couple working on “Resident Evil: Afterlife.” She said, “Paul is the writer, I just ask questions.” He added, “But that’s a hugely important part of the process, and Milla’s really good on script.”

results.title: In Familiar Works, a Chance for Black Film and TV Actors to Shine
results.abstract: On Broadway this fall, it’s less about new playwrights making their debuts and more about established stars giving the stage a shot.

results.title: Stream These 10 Titles Before They Leave Netflix This Month
results.abstract: A bunch of movies and TV shows are leaving the streaming service for U.S. subscribers in September. These are the ones not to miss.

results.title: Amy Stechler, Documentarian Who Helped Define a Style, Dies at 67
results.abstract: She worked on early projects at Florentine Films, where Ken Burns, her husband for a time, would find fame with “The Civil War.”

results.abstract: Regina Hall and Sterling K. Brown star in this satire about a fallen megachurch pastor and his first lady praying and angling for a comeback.

results.title: ‘Loving Highsmith’ Review: The Patricia You Didn’t Know
results.abstract: A new documentary makes the case that under her hardened exterior, the novelist Patricia Highsmith was a longing romantic.

multimedia.caption: The novelist Patricia Highsmith tucked dalliances into her diaries during an era when queer women were obliged to hide their relationships.
The novelist Patricia Highsmith tucked dalliances into her diaries during an era when queer women were obliged to hide their relationships.

results.title: ‘The Cathedral’ Review: A Boy, a Home, a World
results.abstract: In this striking, formally rigorous drama, the director Ricky D’Ambrose revisits his Long Island childhood with restraint and tenderness.

multimedia.caption: In “The Cathedral,” Brian d’Arcy James, center, and Monica Barbaro, far right, play the protagonist’s parents, here at their wedding on Long Island in the 1980s.

results.title: ‘Our American Family’ Review: How Addiction Affects the Household
results.abstract: In this intimate documentary, a Philadelphia family of six reels from a daughter’s recent overdose.

multimedia.caption: When “Our American Family” begins, the 29-year-old Nicole has recently survived an overdose, and must move into a nearby rehab clinic.

results.title: Charlbi Dean, Star of Top Winner at Cannes, Dies at 32

results.title: Virginia Patton Moss, ‘It’s a Wonderful Life’ Actress, Dies at 97
results.abstract: The last surviving adult member of the film’s cast, she played the sister-in-law to James Stewart’s George Bailey. Three years later, she quit Hollywood.

multimedia.caption: Virginia Patton as Ruth Dakin in “It’s a Wonderful Life” (1946) with, from left, Todd Karns as her husband, Harry; James Stewart as George Bailey, Harry's brother; and Thomas Mitchell as the brothers’ Uncle Billy.
